column5: I plan on fixing my boat up a bit this spring, new wood for the seats etc and I was thinking of painting the inside of the boat.  I know about prepping it and all of that, but I was wondering if theres a colour that people prefer to paint the inside.  I want a colour that wont reflect the sunlight directly at me, and wont get stupid hot to the touch.  I've seen a lot of boats with a robins egg blue sort of paint on the inside, is there a reason for this? Can anyone give me an idea of what paint colour works.... heck, even what I should avoid.  thanks ryan
Sand beige.. light grey... or the likes. Nothing I hate worse the Naden's green zinc primer interior..
good call Wayne Their is a reason they paint battleships gray. It helps to cut down on heat reflection and heat retention.   Art
Make sure it's not a glossy finish, semi or matt is better for less reflection.
what? bright yellow didnt make the cut?
Camouflage, so the enemy bombers can't find you as easily out on the lake.  Or mebbe it's the seagulls ....  JF
I used beige rocker panel rubberized spray paint from Canadian tire... it sealed small leaks and it feels great on bare feet! It costs about 8 bucks a can..
how did you like it? and does it come in other colours
thanks. I was thinking either a tan or gray colour actually.  never thought of the rubberized rocker guard stuff though, how has it held up?  ryan
was wonderin if the rubberized rocker guard came in the big cans so i could roll it on or does it only come in spray cans?
i've only ever seen it in spraycans...but i've never looked for it in anything but spraycans...i'll take a look in the next few days when i pick mine up.  ryan
From what i remember it came in "paint can" size..
that would be awesome. I was hoping to paint the inside of my boat .. and was hoping to just roll it on.. but if not im ok with cans
